ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: If premature, weeks gestation at birth
Respondent relationship to child
Interviewer initials
Does your child use words to communicate?
Notes: 0 = Yes: continue; 1 = No: skip to item vi. & vii.; 999 = Missing/NA

ElementDescription: How many different words (that are understandable to familiar adults) does your child use to communicate during a typical day?
Notes: 0 = 1-5 words; 1 = 6-10 words; 2 = 11-30 words; 3 = Greater than 30 words; 999 = Missing/NA

ElementDescription: How many different words (that are understandable to familiar adults) does your child use to communicate during a typical day? - Examples
When did he/she [sic] start using single words?
Notes: 0 = Younger than 24 months; 1 = Older than 24 months; 999 = Missing/NA

ElementDescription: Does your child put together two-word combinations on a daily basis?
How many different phrases (that are understandable to familiar adults) does your child use to communicate?
Notes: 0 = 1-5 phrases; 1 = 6-10 phrases; 2 = 11-30 phrases; 3 = Greater than 30 phrases; 999 = Missing/NA

ElementDescription: How many different phrases (that are understandable to familiar adults) does your child use to communicate? - Examples
Does your child ever mime or use gestures to communicate with you when he/she [sic] doesn't know the word?

Given the above responses and the developmental level of the child, is there evidence of abnormalities in communication that are not compensated for through gesture or miming? (Intro vii. Communication abnormality)
When you smile at your child, how often do they smile back? (1. Response to smile: primary caregiver)
When another familiar adult or caregiver smiles at your child, how often do they smile back? (2. Response to smile: other)

If your child sees other people around them being happy (e.g., at a birthday party), how often do they appear to notice and share those feelings (e.g., smiling, clapping, etc.)? (3. Response to the emotions of others)
How often does your child respond when you call their name?  (5. Response to name)
How often does your child approach other people to play or interact?  (6. Approach others)
How often do they show you things they had done or is doing (e.g., a picture or scribble they drew, a puzzle they completed)?  (7. IJA: proud)

How often does your child try to get you to look at things that interest them (e.g., airplanes, trucks, trains, cute animals), just for the purpose of sharing, not because they want something or needs help?  (8. IJA: interest)

How often does your child engage in back-and-forth babbling (e.g., babbling back when you direct a vocalization to them)? OR How often can you have a short conversation with your child? That is, the child takes two back and forth turns, NOT repetitively asking the same question or only repeating what you say, or ignoring what you say? (9. Back-and-forth conversation)

Does your child enjoy social games such as peek-a-boo, pat-a-cake, Ring around the Rosie, etc.? With follow-up for sometimes/often: do they actively do something to get you to play or continue the game? (10. Enjoy social games)
How often does your child look at you when making a request? (11. Look while requesting)
When your child is trying to get you to look at something, do they look back at you to see if you are looking at the same thing? (12. Look to adult when showing )
How often does your child look at you during physical play (e.g. roughhousing or tickling)? (13. Look during physical play)
How often does your child look at you during social play (e.g., singing a song, playing peek-a- boo)? (14. Look during social play)
How often does your child use these gestures? (If child has no gestures, score 1) (16. Gestures: how often)
If you point at something and say, ''''Look,'''' how often does your child look at the object? (17. Follows point)
How often does your child seem interested in other children?  (18. Interested in children)
When you are at the playground or the park and other children are around, how does your child usually play? (19. Playground park play)
When another child approaches your child to play, how does your child usually respond? (20. Response to approaching child)
How often does your child spontaneously imitate the actions of others without verbal or physical prompting if these are.  (21. Spontaneous imitation)
If your child does pretend play, do they do this with other children, with adults, or only with themself? (23. Pretend play: with others)

How often does your child play with their toys in a specific, inflexible or repetitive way (e.g., lining up toys or objects in the same way each time, putting Legos together only in one specific pattern)?  (24. Inflexible play)
Does your child flap their arms and/or hands? (25. Flapping)
How often does your child make unusual or repetitive movements with their hands or fingers?  (26. Hand/Finger movements)
How often does your child rock back and forth? (27. Rocking)

How often does your child engage in unusual movements with their body (e.g., walking on their toes, jumping repeatedly, spinning, pacing, bouncing from foot to foot, tensing whole body, etc.)? (28. Body movements)

How often does your child make repeated vocalizations or unusual sounds that are not real words? (e.g., screeching and repetitive sounds like "ticka ticka ticka"; not meaningful word approximations) (29. Repeated vocalizations)

How often does your child repeat what you say (immediate echolalia; e.g., saying "You want a cookie" after being asked "Do you want a cookie" and saying "truck" immediately after hearing "Daddy drives a truck")?  (30. Immediate echolalia)
How often does your child repeat phrases, conversations, or lines that they had heard from shows, movies, songs or books, etc. (delayed echolalia)? (31. Delayed echolalia)

Does your child become distressed if activities or conversations are not done the same way each time (e.g., insists that a caregiver says a phrase in the same way every time, becomes distressed if caregiver takes alternate route home in the car, distressed by change in daycare routine)? (32. Routine)

Does your child become distressed or upset if there are minor changes in their immediate environment (e.g., getting new sheets for their bed, changing from shorts to long pants in autumn)? (33. Minor Changes)

Does your child become distressed or upset if minor changes occur in their environment that do not directly affect them (e.g., changing the color of your living room, a caregiver with a new hairstyle or new glasses)? (34. Minor Changes: indirect)

Does your child try to impose their routines or rituals on others (e.g., moving a sibling''s toy cars so that they are in a specific pattern, requiring all who come into your house to remove hats)? (35. Imposes routines/rituals)
Is there anything that your child is interested in that seems like all they want to do? (36. Strong interest)

Does your child enjoy carrying around or playing with items that differ from most children their age (e.g., toilets, hubcaps, lights, spinning objects, vacuum cleaners, string, tools such as pliers, keys, soup cans, hairbrushes, etc.)? (37. Carries objects )
Sum of checks in sensory seeking column (38. Sum of sensory seeking checks)
Sum of checks in hyper-sensitivity column (38. Sum of hyper-sensitivity checks)
Sum of checks in hypo-sensitivity column (38. Sum of hypo-sensitivity checks )
Has your child lost any skills that they had previously mastered? (Regression 1. mastered skills lost)
Deficits in social emotional reciprocity, symptom-level total (DSM-5 A1)
Deficits in nonverbal communication, symptom-level total (DSM-5 A2)
Deficits in relationships, symptom-level total (DSM-5 A3)
Stereotyped/repetitive motor movements, symptom-level total (DSM-5 B1)
Insistence on sameness, symptom-level total (DSM-5 B2)
Restricted, fixated interests, symptom-level total (DSM-5 B3)
Sensory differences, symptom-level total (DSM-5 B4)
TASI overall score (total sum). Interpretation of TASI overall score: less than 7 is low likelihood for ASD, greater than or equal to 7 is elevated likelihood for ASD
